captions.text:
Good morning, Hank. It's Tuesday. The Paper
Towns movie finished shooting a couple days

ago so I am home. I'm tired and a little bit
sick, and as you can probably hear, my voice

has been rode hard and put away wet, but I'm
happy to be home and am so grateful to everybody
who worked so hard on the Paper Towns movie.

So Hank, this is a map of New York created
by the General Drafting Company for the gas

station Esso. I suppose I should explain for
our younger viewers that this is essentially

like a static version of Google Maps printed
on a very large sheet of paper.

But anyway, this particular map is interesting
because where— wait, where are you? Ah!
There you are.

So this map is kind of famous to cartography
nerds and also to readers of Paper Towns because

just north of a little town called Rockland,
New York, it contains Agloe, New York.

Agloe was a town made up by the two guys who
created this map, Ernest G Alpers and Otto

Lindbergh. They took their initials together,
mixed them up, and made Agloe. And then they

put their little fake town in the middle of
nowhere, at the intersection of two dirt roads
in the Catskills.

They did this to protect their copyright.
Mapmakers have always created these little

'paper towns' or 'paper streets' so if they
see them on someone else's map, they'll know
that they've been robbed.

Anyway, flash forward like forty years after
the first General Drafting map with Algoe,

New York on it, Rand McNally makes a map with
Agloe, New York on it.

And when General Drafting calls Rand McNally
to be like "We're gonna sue you" Rand McNally
says, "NONONONO! Agloe is real!"

Because people kept going to that intersection
of two dirt roads in the middle of nowhere,

expecting a place called Agloe, someone built
a place called Agloe. Essentially, Hank, the

story of Agloe, New York is the story of a
fiction that became real.

Now, I would argue that this happens to fictions
and constructions all the time, like I remember

one time in college I told one of my professors
that things that are constructed aren't really

real, and my professor was like, "Well, this
chair is constructed, but if I hit you with
it, it is going to hurt."

The truth is, Hank, the way we imagine the
world does end up shaping reality. And the

book Paper Towns is about how we hurt ourselves
and each other when we imagine other people
as less than human or more than human.

But I guess what interests me most is the
way that our incomplete imaginings of people

and their incomplete imaginings of us end
up shaping our lives really profoundly.

So anyway, back in 2008 I published a story
about how like the merely imagined can, in

my opinion, become really real. And then Agloe,
New York, which had originally been fictional

and then became real and then sort of fell
into disrepair and disappeared again, kind
of became real again.

Readers started making pilgrimages to Agloe,
they found the site of the former Agloe general

store, one of them even made a fake historical
marker which, I guess, come to think of it,
is kind of a real historical marker?

And then, six years later, largely thanks
to readers continuing to care about Q and

Margo and Agloe, people in Hollywood decided
to make a movie, and it all became real again,
in a way.

I got to meet all of these people that I'd
imagined and go inside of their houses and
visit Agloe, New York with them.

Hank, the journey of this to this has been
the weirdest and most wonderful part of what

has been a very weird and wonderful year for
me, personally. So I just wanted to take a

second to thank everyone who's made Paper
Towns real by virtue of reading it and, in
turn, made Agloe real again.

Of course, I know that Agloe will, again,
cease to exist someday, as everything does.

But I think it's pretty cool that, together,
we've made it real for awhile. Thanks for

that. I can't even begin to explain what a
gift it's been for me.
Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

comments.text:
"The store that was Agloe no longer stands. But I believe that if we were 
to put it back on our maps, someone would eventually rebuild it." -John 
Green, Author's Note, Paper Towns. For whatever reason, this line is the 
line that felt like the last line of the novel to me. It made me cry in the 
way the last lines of only really good books can make me do.﻿

comments.author: Brittani Cluett

comments.text:
I love that question, the "what is real?" question. I remember having a 
passionate conversation when I was 14 about whether dragons were real. 
Neither of us thought that there are actual living dragons somewhere, but 
we were trying to figure out if real in our minds, real in a culture or 
story, having real affect on people was enough to make something real. ﻿

comments.text:
On the flip side, in the late 80s/ early 90s, Cincinnati saloonkeeper and 
man about town Jim Tarbell proposed a new baseball stadium for the Reds 
that would be in a more "downtown" location, not cut off from the city by 
Interstate 71 the way Riverfront Stadium was. He had a lifesized brown 
diamond and green outfield painted over some parking lots where he wanted 
the new field to be. 
It didn't happen though; the new stadium did get built, but pretty much 
where the old one was.﻿
comments.author: KFCJones

comments.text:
This is sort of related, maybe. Also, it might not be true...
A developer on Long Island built a bunch of houses on the edge of the town 
of Massapequa. The Long Island Railroad tracks went past his land. To make 
the homes more appealing for prospective buyers, he laid down some 
blacktop, built a shelter, and hung a sign saying Massapequa Park. At 
first, trains just kept whizzing by, by people kept showing up on the 
platforms, trains started stopping there, and at some point it became a 
"real" station.﻿

comments.text:
Must tell you, my wonderful boyfriend bought me a wonderful little box set 
of John Green books. I've read two of them so far in two days, having just 
put down Paper Towns. I need discussion circles because I can't do this on 
the internet. I've no further words to describe how deeply relatable this 
novel felt for me. I am just very happy. All of you humans out there need 
to know: I am just very happy about this book. Go read it.﻿

comments.text:
Wait, just a thought on Agloe, in the mental floss video "44 Fictional 
Character Names Revealed!" at the end you talk about Columbo's name and how 
courts ruled that you can't have copyright on an idea regardless of whether 
or not it is true. Wouldn't this make the point of having agloe on the 
original map pointless?﻿
comments.author: eliot rapoport

comments.text:
You can copyright maps, for various features of design and the selection 
and omission of detail, etc.   I think the point of the original Agloe 
trick not to copyright Agloe itself, but is to make it easy to identify 
(and prove) when another map maker has ripped off  your work.

comments.text:
John, if you see this, and somehow don't know about it, look up the 
sapir-whorf hypothesis.  It's basically the idea that the language we use 
to describe things shapes our understanding of them and, by extension, to 
some sense their reality.  It sounds similar to your ideas (so you probably 
do already know it).﻿

comments.author: chinareds54

comments.text:
It's hard to inspire myself to write a compelling story about my belief and 
what I'm trying to accomplished not knowing if you'll ever read this but 
long story short I have a tale about my peoples lives that needs to be told 
and I believe you're the right person to tell it, the ignorance and 
misinformation of the Venezuelan population has let them to fall in a 
communist regime that is sucking our country dry and making life for us 
hell and yes I know they're are a lot of countries in the world that are 
probably in a worst shape but I just can't stand and do nothing while my 
people literally die because of this government (there are few meds 
available) I just want a chance to tell you my story I don't want credit if 
you publish it I just want Venezuela's truth to be know since most of the 
world doesn't seem to know we exist I'm just a lowly English professor by 
myself I can only change a few minds which is getting harder 'cause I might 
get fired for spreading the little know truth about this regime I really 
need your help to do so, I'm a non-believer but something told me to write 
to you so I hope this get to you I don't ask for much just for my voice to 
be heard I have a lot to say just nobody to listen. P.D I love your books 
they made me recover faith in modern literature, I hope to hear from you.

Best regards

A person trying to fight for justice and what's right﻿
